title: 103_hr2449
content: The Act titled "Depressed Smaller Cities Improvement Act of 1993" establishes an Interagency Task Force on Depressed Smaller Cities. The Interagency Task Force on Depressed Smaller Cities is established with 9 members including representatives from various government departments and 5 members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Interagency Task Force on Depressed Smaller Cities consists of 9 members, including public officials from depressed smaller cities appointed for a 6-month period. Members must have geographical diversity and serve for the life of the Task Force. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is the chairperson, and members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Interagency Task Force on Depressed Smaller Cities consists of 9 members appointed for a 6-month period. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development chairs the Task Force, and members are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Task Force will study problems in depressed smaller cities, including crime, environment, housing, labor, education, health, and poverty. They will analyze existing programs, coordination among them, effectiveness, and determine Federal assistance needed. Consultation with local officials will be done to implement measures before completing the study. The Task Force will submit annual reports to the House and Senate committees detailing their activities, findings, and determinations from the study on problems affecting depressed smaller cities. The reports will also identify the most pervasive issues in these cities. The Task Force will submit annual reports to the House and Senate committees detailing their activities, findings, and determinations from the study on problems affecting depressed smaller cities. The reports will also identify the most pervasive issues in these cities, including efforts to alleviate problems, immediate and long-term needs, existing Federal programs, an agenda of actions, and recommendations for actions and legislation. The Task Force will submit a final report to Congress upon completion of their study on issues affecting depressed smaller cities. Meetings will be held quarterly to conduct the study and prepare reports. Identification of depressed smaller cities. The term "depressed smaller city" is defined as a municipality with a population of less than 50,000 and more than 5,000, meeting specific criteria related to unemployment, crime rate, and lack of municipal health facilities. The term "depressed smaller city" refers to a municipality with a population of less than 50,000 and more than 5,000, meeting specific criteria related to unemployment, crime rate, lack of municipal health facilities, low income levels, and environmental problems resulting from industrial activities. The Commission will terminate after a 3-year period from the appointment of the Task Force. $750,000 is authorized for this Act, available in fiscal years 1995, 1996, and 1997.
